Project Description

The  Project  will  support  the  transfer  to  beneficiaries  of  the
ownership and maintenance of irrigation systems covering about
10,000  hectares  (ha).  The  transfer  of  assets  is  expected  to  be
complemented by the establishment of water user associations
(WUAs),  rehabilitation  of  infrastructure,  and  enhancement  of
extension  capacity.  A  sector  approach  is  proposed  to  be
adopted. Prospective subprojects will be located in 17 districts in
six  provinces  identified  on  the  basis  of  specific  criteria.  A
detailed  feasibility  study  has  been  completed  for  two  core
subprojects  in  Nakhong  and  Chom  Thong,  in  consultation  with
stakeholders,  and  the  financial  and  economic  viability  of  the
rehabilitation  program  established.  The  Project  will  provide
WUAs  with  support  for  developing  their  capacity  in  financial
management  and  market  development.  WUAs  are  expected  to
implement  proposed  cost  recovery  measures.  Rehabilitation  of
irrigation  systems  will  include  repairs  to  the  pump  sets,  and
review  of  the  appropriateness  of  the  present  design  of  the
headworks  and  distribution  systems.  Extension  support  will  be
through  provision  of  specialist  services  for  technology  transfer
and  training  of  local  officials.  Extension  capacity  will  be
enhanced  by  provision  of  training,  training  materials,  and  field
study  tours  for  farmers  and  select  officials  to  familiarize  them
with suggested best practices.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1.

General

3.
The  Lao  PDR  is  a  landlocked  country  spread  over  about  236,800  square  kilometers
(km2),  with  a  population  of  around  5.07  million.  The  population  is  broadly  classified  into  three
groups:  Lao  Loum,  Lao  Theung,  and  Lao  Soung.  Lao  Loum  is  the  largest  ethnic  group
representing  about  42  percent  of  the  population  and  residing  in  the  low-lying  areas  of  the
Mekong  River  and  its  major  tributaries.  Population  density  is  very  low  at  19  persons/km2,  and
ranges between 9 persons/km2 in the rural areas to 134 persons/km2 in Vientiane. About 4.15
million  people  (82  percent)  live  in  rural  areas.  The  country  is  divided  into  16  provinces,  one
special  region  (Xaisomboun),  and  Vientiane  Municipality.  Each  is  headed  by  a  governor,
assisted  by  field  officials  from  central  ministries.  In  1998,  the  Government  announced  its
intention to move toward a more decentralized form of governance in several sectors, including
agriculture and forestry.

4.
Per capita gross domestic product (GDP) is estimated at around $281. Lack of physical
infrastructure  remains  a  major  constraint  to  economic  development.  The  general  economic
downturn in Asia in recent years has eroded the local currency and resulted in rampant inflation.
To address the situation, the Government initiated a series of macroeconomic policy measures
designed to stabilize the kip and reduce inflation. Following the admission of the Lao PDR to the
Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN),  considerable  potential  to  exploit  export
markets has been created. This would improve with the scheduled 2005 implementation of the
ASEAN Free Trade Area (AFTA) under ASEAN and entry into the World Trade Organization.

2.

Economic Importance of Agriculture

5.
Although industry and services have been contributing much to GDP—about 22 percent
and 25 percent, respectively—agriculture is still the largest contributor, with 53 percent share in
GDP.  However,  agricultural  production  is  low  due  to  inefficient  practices,  such  as  lack  of  timely
and adequate inputs like fertilizer and seed, and weak output markets. Rice is the major crop. The
irrigated areas on the floodplains of the Mekong River and its major tributaries produce most of
the  marketable  rice.  Due  to  the  difficult  terrain  and  poorly  developed  internal  and  external
transport  system,  most  areas  away  from  the  Mekong  River  are  relatively  isolated  from  the
lowland  areas  of  the  country.  With  a  small  population,  minimal  monetization  of  the  rural
economy,  and  low  demand  for  diversified  products,  the  opportunity  for  internal  market
expansion  is  limited.  However,  with  its  smaller  population  and  abundant  but  largely  untapped
natural  resources,  which  include  water  and  land,  the  country  is  in  a  position  to  produce  for
export to neighboring markets.

About 95 percent of the rural population depends on income from agricultural production,
6.
mainly rice. Field studies undertaken at proposed subproject sites showed that more than half the
potential beneficiaries are farmers having access to holdings less than 1.5 ha in size. Close to two
thirds of these farmers have less than 1 ha under irrigation. Socioeconomic surveys have shown
annual household incomes varying between KN2.5 million and KN25.0 million ($330-$3,300) per
household per year.

7.
The Government continues to emphasize the need for food security because annual rice
production remains sensitive to the weather. Emphasis is placed on a second rice crop in the dry
season to compensate for losses due to floods in lowlands. Simultaneously, traditional agriculture
is  undergoing  a  process  of  change  due  to  many  external  influences  such  as  market  prices,
improved  seed,  fertilizer,  credit,  mechanization  and  new  technology.  Farmers  must  learn  to
effectively increase agricultural production in a market economy by exploiting the market better and
adopting  new  technology.  The  Government  recently  formulated  an  agriculture  sector  strategy  for
the  country,  with  assistance  from  ADB.  The  strategy  (para.  23)  sets  the  stage  for  more  market-
oriented  development  of  the  sector  and  emphasizes  the  need  for  increased  income-earning
opportunities in the sector.

3.

Irrigation Subsector

8.
Irrigation systems in the Lao PDR are small by international standards. Only six systems
have a command area exceeding 1,000 ha, with the largest system covering only 4,500 ha. If
the  six  largest  systems  are  excluded,  the  designed  average  command  area  of  the  remaining
systems  is  less  than  500  ha  and,  in  many  cases,  the  actual  irrigated  area  is  far  less  than  the
designed  area.  The  Department  of  Irrigation  (DOI)  reported  that,  in  1998,  there  were  about
1,840 irrigation systems with a wet season capacity of approximately 200,000 ha. This is about
25  percent  of  the  country’s  reported  800,000  ha  of  annually  cultivated  land.  The  dry  season
irrigated area was reported at about 98,000 ha, but the actual irrigated area may be less than
that officially reported.

9.
Irrigation systems on the lowland floodplains are usually supplied with water from rivers
pumped by diesel or electric pumps. A number of the pump irrigation systems on the floodplains
were built in the late seventies, and function with varying degrees of efficiency. Many initially used
diesel pumps because of the poor rural power distribution system, but the use of electric pumps is
increasing.  Even  now  agriculture  consumes  only  about  6  percent  of  the  total  power,  but

 3

consumption is growing at a significant rate. Major problems facing most systems are the recurrent
costs of electricity and the occasional cost of major repairs or rehabilitation of pumps, motors and
switching  gear.  After  initial  construction,  many  well-functioning  large  pump  systems  received
additional  technical  and  investment  support  from  external  agencies  through  projects  such  as  the
Sustainable  Irrigated  Agriculture  Project  (SIRAP).2  These  projects  have  concentrated  on  the
establishment of well-functioning water user associations (WUAs) as a means of promoting system
sustainability.

In  the  mid-1990s  in  pursuance  of  a  strategy  to  improve  food  production  during  the  dry
10.
season, the Government installed a large number of pontoon-mounted pumps, powered by electric
motors where electricity is available, or by diesel engines. In some cases, the pumps replaced old
or unserviceable pumps at fully developed irrigation systems. Commonly, though, the pumps were
installed  at  new  sites  with  only  head  works  constructed  but  no  adequate  technical  input  or
supervision.  Construction  of  the  distribution  infrastructure  remained  the  responsibility  of  the
irrigators and was executed without any standard technical specification being followed and without
adequate supervision.

4.

Development Issues

a. 

Operation and Maintenance

11.
Irrigation  systems  in  the  Lao  PDR  suffer  from  low  levels  of  maintenance.  Farmers
belonging  to  the  larger  irrigation  systems  on  the  river  plains  have  relied  on  the  Government  to
maintain  the  infrastructure.  With  increasing  pressure  on  the  national  budget,  DOI  has  been
allocating almost all the available budget for capital works to expand the area under irrigation to
satisfy  political  demands,  and  has  allocated  virtually  no  budget  for  O&M.  Funds  are  made
available on an ad hoc basis, or aid agencies are pressed to assist whenever repairs are of an
urgent  nature.  As  a  result  most  of  the  systems  have  become  run  down.  To  improve  O&M,  DOI
has adopted the IMT approach under which assets are transferred to the beneficiaries so that they
bear  the  cost  of  O&M.  However,  this  is  being  done  without  adequate  preparation  and  requires
technical  support.  Farmers  are  beginning  to  understand  that  the  responsibility  for  irrigation
maintenance  lies  with  them  and  it  is  necessary  to  establish  well-functioning  WUAs  for  this
purpose.

b. 

Availability and Distribution of Inputs

Under the ongoing Lao-IRRI Project, the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) has
12.

disseminated in about 80 percent of the area under rice in the lowlands. While the facilities for
seed multiplication are adequate, demand is not adequate because farmers do not understand
the need to periodically replace their seed material. The Government also allows import of seed.

13.

through  a  Japanese  Government  grant,  and  distributed  by  the  Agricultural  Promotion  Bank
(APB) as credit in kind. It is not subsidized and the Government has found this to be a useful
means  of  keeping  the  prices  of  imported  fertilizer  in  check.  Private  entrepreneurs  have  also

14.
Providing access to financial services is integral to the Government’s efforts to improve
agricultural  productivity  and  rural  incomes.  Most  credit  for  agricultural  purposes  is  extended
through APB, which was set up in 1993. Funds are generally provided by the Bank of Lao PDR
for various purposes and APB is also used to deliver external assistance for agricultural credit.
A  detailed  review  of  the  rural  financial  sector  revealed  that  APB  does  not  operate  on  a  viable
basis and its coverage of the rural areas is inadequate. There is need to encourage the private
sector to provide credit in the rural areas, and the Bank of Lao PDR must develop the capacity
to train staff in rural credit functions. To address this need, technical assistance from ADB3 has
been extended, which is expected to reform APB and improve its coverage and efficiency.

c. 

Extension Support and Decentralization

15. While  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Forestry  (MAF)  provides  extension  services,  its
efforts have not been well coordinated and have not produced the desired impact. This is mainly
because  extension  was  not  fully  understood  and  was  treated  more  as  an  information

Lessons Learned

32.
The main lessons incorporated in the project design concern farmer-managed irrigation,
which will only be sustainable if (i) WUAs receive sufficient training and are allowed to operate
effectively  with  financial  management  and  all  technical  aspects  of  irrigation  operation,
management,  and  maintenance;  (ii)  farmers  understand  and  accept  that  they  are  fully
responsible  for  all  aspects  of  irrigation  system  operations,  management,  and  maintenance;
(iii) physical repair/rehabilitation work is undertaken properly with adequate attention to survey,
design, construction, and quality control so as to provide a system sufficient to give irrigators the
means to increase production as anticipated; (iv) profit from crop production remains sufficient
to  allow  for  cost  recovery;  and  (v)  private  sector  support  for  the  supply  of  agricultural  inputs,
including reliable technical service supplies and spare parts, are available direct to farmers, at
competitive market prices. Finally, to ensure sustainability, the Government has to continue to
extend  extension  and  technical  support  to  the  systems  even  when  the  transfer  process  is
completed.

33.
SIRAP developed a process for IMT based on five major steps involving two phases: the
preparation phase and the implementation phase. The process proceeds in a linear fashion with
continuous  attention  and  priority  to  (i)  WUA  development,  (ii)  crop  development  and  related
agricultural  extension  activities,  (iii)  market  development,  (iv)  improved  access  to  and  use  of
agricultural inputs, and (v) appropriate O&M. The SIRAP process, developed through extensive
field testing, has been demonstrated to be effective in establishing and strengthening WUAs to
the point where they are capable of managing the normal operation of the irrigation systems. In
addition, it is necessary for the Government to strengthen the support services.

34.
A  large  body  of  lessons  from  completed  similar  ADB  projects  and  special  impact
evaluation studies have been taken into account. The International Water Management Institute
(IWMI)  has  undertaken  considerable  research  on  IMT  and  has  provided  a  comprehensive
analysis  of  the  prerequisites  to  ensure  the  success  of  this  process.  IWMI  states  that  an
adequate  framework  for  irrigation  development  must  address  (i)  legal  issues,  (ii)  governance,
(iii)  organization,  and  (iv)  finance.  IWMI  recognized  that  these  aspects  overlap  and  should  be
addressed  simultaneously.  A  successful  national  framework  for  irrigation  would  consider  clear,
secure,  and  transferable  water  rights;  decentralized  management  organizations;  the  role  of  the
government  as  facilitator  and  regulator,  not  controller;  accountability  of  all  parties;  and  financial
autonomy and sustainability.14

per  ha  per  year,  depending  on  the  type  of  irrigation  system  and  its  requirements.  At  present

46.

8.

Budget for Rehabilitation

47.
Most of the budget of DOI at national and provincial levels is for construction of irrigation
infrastructure, in keeping with the Government’s policy to increase dry season food production.
Expenditure is incurred mainly for new construction activities, and very little provision is made
for  rehabilitation  or  maintenance.  The  Government’s  explanation  is  that  the  assets  are
constructed and then handed over to beneficiaries for maintenance; hence, there is no need for
any  maintenance  expenditure.  A  special  budget  is  sought  in  case  of  damage  due  to  natural
calamities.  However,  with  the  recommendation  under  the  agriculture  sector  strategy,  the
Government is keen to divert increased investments to rehabilitation. The Government agreed
that at least 15 percent of the national as well as the provincial budgets of the project provinces
would  be  earmarked  for  rehabilitation  and  maintenance  of  irrigation  assets  from  2001.  This
would be progressively increased and reach 30 percent by project completion. The adequacy of
this allocation would be reviewed during the midterm review of the Project.

48.
Irrigation systems constructed over the last two decades vary in size. While the upland
systems have generally relied on small diversion weirs and distribution by gravity, the majority of
the systems in the lowlands along the Mekong River are pump irrigation schemes. Many have
been  in  existence  for  over  five  years,  but  have  been  poorly  maintained  and  hence  do  not
function efficiently. The schemes established between 1996 and 1998 under the Government’s

realized their potential. A program of systematically rehabilitating existing irrigation systems with
specific attention to their sustainability, especially in the lowlands, will significantly improve the

Budget constraints force the Government to allocate inadequate amounts for rehabilitation and
O&M;  hence,  there  is  no  systematic  program  for  rehabilitation  and  O&M  of  existing  irrigation

The  project  area  is  largely  in  the  plains  along  the  Mekong  and  its  major  tributaries.  The

c.

Enhancement of Extension Capacity

58.
An agricultural extension system is necessary to raise farmer awareness of and ability to
use  new  technologies.  An  effective  extension  system  will  develop  farmer  capacity  to  identify
constraints, try new technologies, and make decisions for ongoing improvements in production.
This component includes specialist services for technology transfer for more suitable cropping
patterns, adoption of improved seed, more efficient use of fertilizer, and better water utilization.

familiarize them with suggested best practices. While training is designed to enhance capacity
at 6 PAFSOs, 17 DAFSOs, and in the 56 WUAs, the emphasis is on strengthening the district-
level capacity to provide know-how and guide agronomic practices.

Financial and Economic Analyses

1.

Quantifiable Benefits

89.
By the end of the Project, about 56 well-functioning and appropriately trained WUAs will
have  been  established  in  as  many  irrigation  schemes  covering  about  10,000  ha.  The
participating farmers will also have received extension training to adopt modern and appropriate
crop  production  and  marketing  techniques  to  significantly  improve  productivity  and  incomes.
The IMT process will ensure that WUAs are financially self-sufficient and technically capable of
carrying  out  the  necessary  O&M  for  their  irrigation  systems  on  a  sustainable  basis.
Rehabilitation of each batch of proposed subprojects will be implemented over two years. During
the  first  year,  WUAs  will  be  established,  farmers  will  be  trained,  and the  extension  program  will
commence.  In  the  second  year,  detailed  design  and  rehabilitation  works  will  be  carried  out  in
close cooperation with the beneficiaries. It is assumed that benefits will begin to accrue in the last
year of the rehabilitation works. The quantified benefits from the IMT process will include (i) about
10 percent increase in the irrigated area; (ii) 10-15 percent increase in cropping intensity; (iii) 50
and 65 percent increase in the wet and dry season paddy yields, respectively; and (iv) adoption of
high-value crops on about 20 percent of the cropped area.

2.

90.
A  wide  range  of  nonquantified  benefits  will  result  from  the  Project.  The  improved  and
more productive subprojects will contribute to national and local food security. Direct employment
opportunities  will  increase  as  a  result  of  more  intensified  farming  and  increased  irrigated  area.
Indirect employment opportunities in marketing, processing of farm products and farm services
will also expand. Organizations of women’s groups will gradually expand their role and influence
in  the  decision-making  process.  The  IMT  process  itself  will  strengthen  the  WUAs  by  making
them more sustainable in the long run. Other benefits that are not quantified but are significant will

92.
The  successful  implementation  of  the  Project  will  lead  to  the  complete  phasing  out  of
subsidies on O&M for the proposed 56 schemes and, to the extent the Project is replicated, for
all  irrigation  schemes  in  the  country.  In  the  proposed  financing  approach,  it  is  envisaged  that
farmers will cover all costs of routine O&M and will build up a corpus to meet part of the costs of
the  periodic  replacement  or  repair  of  major  capital  items.  Successful  WUAs  are  expected  to
become eligible for medium- and long-term loans from public and private commercial banks that
would enable them to raise capital for replacing equipment and further improving and expanding
their  irrigation  schemes.  Farmer  payments  to  the  VDF  will  reduce  claims  on  the  Government
budget. As originally proposed by the Government, 20 percent of these payments would pass
out of the village to the district development fund, and 80 percent would stay in the village and
enable farmers to finance local initiatives, including expenses related to irrigation.

4.

Economic Analysis

93.
Economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  two  core  subprojects.  The  estimated  EIRRs
were 22.6 for Nakhong and 24.0 percent for Chom Thong. The analysis includes the capital and
support costs during the two-year implementation of individual subprojects and recurrent cost of
O&M for the assumed 15-year life of the subprojects. The economic benefits were estimated in
constant 2000 prices and the world price numeraire was used. The economic farmgate prices of
internationally  traded  commodities  (rice,  maize,  and  soybean)  and  fertilizers  (urea  and
diammonium phosphate) were derived from the World Bank Commodity Price Projections (April
2000) and adjusted for port handling, transportation, and processing costs. The economic price
of crop seed was considered to be 20 percent higher than the respective commodity price.

94.
The  sensitivity  analysis  suggests  that  a  20  percent  decrease  in  agricultural  benefits
(yields) would reduce the EIRR to 17.3 in Nakhong and 18.7 percent in Chom Thong. Similarly,
a 20 percent increase in the rehabilitation (cash) costs would reduce the EIRR to 19.4 and 21.3,
respectively. A simultaneous 20 percent decrease in benefits and 20 percent increase in (cash)
costs would reduce the EIRR to 14.6 and 15.8 percent, respectively, for these subprojects.

5.

Sustainability

95.
Project  sustainability  will  be  contingent  on  the  technical  support  provided  and  financial
viability of farmers. The extent to which the Government is subsidizing the irrigation subsector is
unclear. The budgetary situation in the Lao PDR imposes major limitations on the Government’s
subsidy  for  O&M.  Power  is  provided  at  a  subsidized  cost  as  part  of  the  Government’s  normal
pricing policy, but a process is in place to continually increase its tariff to a market price. There
are  no  subsidies  on  fertilizer  or  seed  supply.  The  Government  subsidizes  the  subsector  to  a
limited  extent  by  providing  ad  hoc assistance  for  emergency  and  major  repairs  to  irrigation
infrastructure,  but  the  actual  allocation  for  this  assistance  is  difficult  to  determine.  It  appears
there are no significant distortions in the output or input markets. With improved irrigation sector
efficiency and after IMT implementation, savings to the treasury can be expected. It may then
be possible to allocate more resources to technical supervision and extension service. Both will
be critical to the sustainability of the Project and IMT program.

Impact on Poverty

The  Project  is  aimed  at  farmers  who  make  up  over  90  percent  of  the  rural  poor  –  the
estimated  rural  poverty  line  is  KN83,000  ($11)/capita/month.23  Almost  two  thirds  of  all  farming

Increased rice yields will ensure that these shortages do not occur in the beneficiary households.
The impact will be particularly significant in the poorer households.

C.

Risks

99.
Three principal project risks pertain to (i) implementation, (ii) realization of benefits, and (iii)
sustainability.  Crosscutting  concerns  for  all  three  categories  are  the  level  of  motivation  and
capacity of farmers, the implementation capacity and adequate number of Government staff, and
adequacy of extension services.

100. Project  implementation  will  be  affected  if  there  is  no  interest  on  the  part  of  the
beneficiaries.  While  the  demonstration  effect  of  SIRAP  is  expected  to  make  the  beneficiaries
keen to accept ownership of the assets, it also means that there are greater costs to bear for
them. The experience with respect to collecting O&M costs in the SIRAP subprojects has been
encouraging.  The  advantages  of  the  IMT  process  and  expected  gains  must  be  adequately
explained  and  the  beneficiaries  educated  and  trained  to  become  willing  to  participate  in  the
process.  Close  monitoring,  technical  supervision,  support  through  assured  inputs  supply,  etc.,
would be necessary to build confidence. The extension support and specific institutional support
for the WUAs are to address these risks. Feasibility studies will be undertaken in all subprojects,
with  the  full  participation  of  beneficiaries,  to  establish  incentives  for  farmer  participation  during
planning, implementation, and routine O&M.

The  institutional  capacity  of  DOI,  PAFSOs,  and  DAFSOs  is  an  equally  important  risk.
101.
The management capability of DOI and PAFSOs has been carefully assessed and the project
scope  was  determined  on  that  basis.  Project  management  support  will  be  provided  for
subproject  appraisal,  design  development,  training  of  extension  staff,  and  BME.  The
Government  must  ensure  that  adequate  and  trained  staff,  who  have  gained  experience  under
FIAT and PEP, are appointed in the project area. While the Government has agreed to appoint
more women extension staff, past experience indicates that, for personal reasons, many women
leave  after  being  trained.  To  the  extent  possible,  this  must  be  taken  into  account  in  the
appointment of women staff.

102. Some specific measures have been incorporated to mitigate implementation risk: (i) site
selection will be determined by technical and social considerations; (ii) survey and design will be
undertaken  at  provincial  level  where  the  capability  exists,  but  SSDC  staff  will  be  permanently
assigned  to  the  provinces  during  the  survey  and  design  process;  (iii)  DOI  has  developed
standards to be followed for survey, design, and construction; (iv) care will be taken in selecting
prequalified  contractors,  with  selection  being  based  on  known  past  performance;  and  (v)  the
team  leader  of  the  project  management  team  will  be  party  to  all  decisions  on  contract
management, including matters on contractor disqualification and/or dismissal.

103. Realizing the expected level of benefits is contingent on the Government being able to
provide  an  effective  combination  of  policy  environment,  extension  services,  and  timely  and
adequate supply of inputs. Budget support for nonsalary recurring costs for extension support is
essential  and  needs  to  be  maintained  after  project  completion.  The  Government  contribution
through the budget to meet its share of project cost needs close monitoring. Market-determined
prices are expected to result in higher returns to farmers. The Government needs to pursue the
opening  up  of  export  markets.  It  must  ensure  availability  of  inputs  and  take  steps  to  allow  the
private sector to supply inputs. The extension service is important to ensure that inputs are used
efficiently. Productivity can only increase with better technology transfer relating to use of inputs.
Quality  of  inputs  like  seeds  needs  to  be  improved.  These  are  the  specific  areas  in  which
institutional strengthening activities will be directed and technical assistance provided to WUAs
to  help  develop  market  intelligence.  The  risk  to  expectations  regarding  export  markets  is  the
policy environment in neighboring countries as well as comparative costs of production.

104. Sustainability  of  the  IMT  process  and  efficient  agriculture  depend  primarily  on  the
efficient  functioning  of  the  WUAs  and  their  ability  to  maintain  the  irrigation  systems,  manage
O&M funds, and provide marketing and service support. Ways and means of effectively forming
WUAs  and  improving  their  technical  and  managerial  capabilities  have  been  explored  during
project formulation and will be pursued during implementation.

of  the  provinces  were  limited.  Further,  it  was  considered  necessary  to  take  into  account  the
number  of  potential  subproject  sites  in  each  province  to  allow  limited  human  resources  to  be
deployed efficiently. The proposed investment in institutional strengthening and human resource
development  at  the  district  level  was  intended  to  have  maximum  impact.  On  this  basis,
17 districts were identified in these provinces.1

B.

Screening Criteria

3.
For any individual subproject site to be selected, its system must have a minimum irrigated
area of 200 ha in the wet season, or 50 in the dry season. Importance was then placed on social
aspects, in particular poverty reduction in selecting the subprojects.

4.
All  sites  initially  suggested  as  potential  subprojects  were  carefully  screened  for  social
concerns.    As  a  first  step,  the  following  criteria  that  considered  social  factors,  gender,  and
viability  of  the  transfer  process  were  developed:  (i)  poverty  level  in  villages,  (ii)  community
capability, (iii) interest and capacity for irrigation management transfer, (iv) gender aspects, (v)
supportive  context,  (vi)  secure  access  to  water  and  land,  (vii)  agronomic  aspects,  and  (viii)
availability of infrastructure.

An in-depth survey of all initially selected schemes was then organized to determine to
5.
what  extent they  meet  the  various  criteria. The survey was carried out by experienced project
staff  of  Farmer  Irrigated  Agriculture  Training  Project  familiar  with  local  conditions,  in  close
consultation with the concerned provincial agriculture and forestry service offices (PAFSOs) and
district agriculture and forestry service offices. The survey was designed to estimate the income
of beneficiary households. It was decided not only to rely on estimated household incomes but
also  to  use  a  number  of  indicators  of  wealth  and  income.  It  was  recognized  that  the
socioeconomic  well-being  of  households  and  villages  is  not  only  expressed  in  household
income, but also reflected size and nature of landholdings, quantity of rice produced, household
possessions (like radio, motorbike, TV, refrigerator), and availability of infrastructure facilities in
the  village  (like  health  post,  secondary  school,  all-weather  road).  In  the  final  selection,  the
pattern of socioeconomic indicators was considered: sites that scored consistently high on the
various  indicators  (i.e.,  appearing  to  be  consistently  better  off  than  other  sites  in  the  survey)
were excluded and sites that appeared to be consistently poorer were included. The screening

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES

A.

Introduction

1.
Over 500 pump irrigation schemes built since the late 1970s now function with varying
degrees of efficiency. Most have a command area of 80-300 hectares (ha). Initially, many had
diesel pumps due to the poor rural power distribution system. However, a great majority of them
now  have  electric  pumps.  In  addition  to  these  schemes,  over  200  new  schemes  were
established after 1996 under the National Irrigation Management Program (NIMP) and pumps at
several of the old schemes were replaced. Invariably, most of the schemes are in the Mekong
River  plains  and  do  not  have  an  efficient  water  distribution  system.  For  their  operation  and
maintenance  (O&M),  the  Government  bears  a  heavy  fiscal  burden.  Under  the  Dutch-funded
Sustainable  Irrigated  Agriculture  Project  (SIRAP)  completed  in  1998,  the  concept  of  irrigation
management  transfer  (IMT)  was  pilot-tested  in  eight  such  schemes  by  establishing  well-
functioning  water  users  associations  (WUAs).  The  SIRAP  experience  demonstrated  that  well-
trained WUAs can take over such schemes from the Government and provide for their O&M on
a sustainable basis. Under the proposed Project, IMT will result in significant fiscal savings for
the  Government  while  the  efficiency  of  the  schemes  will  help  increase  farm  productivity  and
incomes of the beneficiaries.

2.

selected for detailed analysis, i.e., Nakhong in Vientiane Province and Chom Thong in Vientiane

main crop in both the wet and dry season. Soybean, maize, and vegetables are other crops in
this area. Due to its proximity to Vientiane, Chom Thong has a larger more area for vegetables
than for the two other crops.

3.

Agricultural Benefits

11.
The Project will (i) organize farmers into WUAs and train them to carry out O&M of the
schemes and adopt improved farming practices, and (ii) rehabilitate the pump stations and the
water  distribution  network.  The  direct  benefits  of  these  investments,  measured  as  the
incremental net value of agricultural production, will be achieved from about 10 percent increase
in  the  irrigated  area,  5-10  percent  increase  in  cropping  intensity,  50  percent  increase  in  wet
season and 65 percent increase in dry season paddy yields,3 and about 10-15 percent increase
in  vegetable  yields.  There  would  also  be  a  switch  in  cropped  area  from  relatively  low  value
crops  such  as  paddy  to  higher  value  crops  like  maize  and  vegetables.  Significant  yield
increases will result from adoption of better seed, more and efficient use of fertilizers, and better
farming  and crop protection  practices. An appropriately designed and well-executed extension
component will ensure that farmers get the requisite training and are able to optimize the project
investment. These expectations are realistic and are based on experiences gained from recent
pilot  projects,  i.e.,  SIRAP.  Data  for  cropping  patterns,  cropping  intensity,  area,  yield,  and
production for these three sites in without- and with-Project scenarios are presented in Tables
A9.1 and A9.2.

12.
Irrigation  efficiencies  will  also  increase  significantly.  Currently,  most  pumps  do  not
operate at full capacity for want of minor repairs and/or lack of technical knowledge among the
farmers.  Most  of  the  distribution  network  is  not  properly  designed  to  carry  water  to  farm  fields
efficiently.  A  redesigned  and  rehabilitated  distribution  network  will  considerably  improve
irrigation efficiency as well as equity and also ensure timely availability of water at crucial stages
of crop development. These improvements in irrigation will induce farmers to adopt better seed
and apply more fertilizers to realize higher yields.

B.

Financial Analysis

13.
To determine the financial viability of the Project, detailed farm models were prepared for
both  sites.  Detailed  interviews  on  input/output  parameters  with  representative  farmers  were
undertaken at each site.4 Household size and/or cropping practices do not significantly vary, but
landholding patterns slightly vary.

1. 

Feasibility Study Sites

14.
Nakhong, Vientiane Province.  The site is 40 kilometers (km) north of Vientiane. The
irrigation  system  has  150  ha  with  111  landowners  using  the  irrigated  land.  Holdings  per
household vary from 0.32 ha to 4 ha. Average farm size is about 1.5 ha. About 40 percent of the
holdings are of that size, while 20 percent are above average.

15.
Chom Thong, Vientiane Municipality. The site is around 20 km east of Vientiane, on
the banks of the Mekong River. The irrigation system has 250 ha, and 467 landowners use the
irrigated land.  Holdings per household vary from 0.16 ha to 1.6 ha. Average farm size is 0.5 ha.

by adopting improved farming methods and without any additional inputs.
The data were compared with those in other key studies, particularly the Community-Managed Irrigation Project

2.

The Current Situation

16.
The typical household comprises six persons, of whom two are of school age. Farming
systems are currently fairly similar in both sites. Rice production is predominant in the wet and
dry  seasons.  While  other  options  may  be  more  profitable,  in  the  current  environment  where
water  management  is  erratic,  fresh  produce  is  difficult  to  both  store  and  transport,  and
competition  from  cheaper  imports  can  lead  to  significant  market  price  variations.  Given  this
situation, farmers are making rational choices by favoring rice production.

Some vegetables, around 0.16 ha per household, are grown, generally adjacent to the
17.

command  area  is  restricted  to  rice.  Other  crops  would  drown  in  the  “all  or  nothing”  delivery
system currently in place. Rice yields per hectare are fairly constant: around 2.0 t/ha in the wet
season and 3.0 t/ha in the dry season. However, wet season yields are a little higher in Chom
Thong where use of improved seed allows yields of around 2.8 t/ha.

Larger  farmers  tend  to  have  their  own  machinery  such  as  a  walking  tractor.  Threshing  is  also
done by contract for 5 percent of the yield. Pesticides are not used and farmers currently pay

3.

Project Financial Impact on Average Household

20.
After  the  rehabilitation,  two  types  of  levies,  such  as  ISF  and  VDF,  will  be  collected  to
ensure routine O&M and the long-term sustainability of the subprojects. Financial analysis, based
on the site-specific farm models, indicates that after project implementation, farmers will raise their
incomes significantly and be able to afford the levies.

ISF will be established to provide full O&M funds for each irrigation system. The average
21.
ISF  required  to  achieve  this  objective  has  been  estimated  at  $29/ha/year  (or  315  kg  of
paddy/ha/year) at full development, considering future power tariff. However, farmers are already
paying  around  $5.5/ha/year  to  WUG  for  power  cost.  In  addition,  they  will  contribute  around
$5.0/ha/year  in  labor.  Thus,  the  additional  cash  cost  for  ISF  at  the  future  power  rate  will  be
$18.5/ha/year. However, with improved irrigation efficiency, power consumption may be reduced
by 20 percent.

VDF will be levied after the IMT process is complete. The Government has established its
22.
rate  according  to  the  type  of  irrigation  scheme.  For  gravity,  electric  pump,  and  diesel  pump
schemes, VDF will be levied at the rate of 200 ($18), 150 ($14), and 100 kg ($9) of paddy/ha/year,
respectively. For electric pumps, 80 percent of the revenue will stay with the WUA and the rest will
pass on to the district treasury. In case of diesel pumps, WUA will keep 95 percent of revenues.
VDF is payable for a period of no more than 20 years, or until the capital costs are recovered. One
important objective of the levy is to recover a portion of the sunk costs or rehabilitation costs of
Government investment in irrigation schemes. The fund may be re-distributed to the wider village
community to finance small-scale village social development projects or fund emergency repairs
to irrigation equipment.

23.
To be able to fund these additional costs, farmers will need to make adjustments to their
farming  systems.  However,  such  changes  will  have  to  take  account  of  agronomic  practices,
household  labor,  market  access,  and  risk  management.  The  farming  system  will  continue  to  be
rice based, but the area of other more profitable crops will marginally increase. These options will
vary  according  to  location.  Farmers  in  Chom  Thong,  for  example,  will  be  able  to  expand  their
vegetable area while those in Nakhong will expand the area of less perishable crops, i.e., maize.
The gross margin for irrigated paddy is $165/ha, or $1.61/person-day, that for improved irrigated
maize  is  $340/ha  or  $7.83/person-day.  However,  any  expected  expansion  of  other  crops  takes
into account the household’s food security as a priority.

24.
With improved and more reliable access to adequate flows of water, vegetable income will
also  increase.  Where  farmers  are  now  restricted  to  two  vegetable  crops  per  dry  season,  e.g.,
cucumber or spring onion, they will be able to produce three crops. However, due to realities of
market access, this option is assumed only for the Chom Thong site. In Nakhong, field crops, i.e.,
maize  or  soybeans,  are  assumed  to  be  taken  up  as  more  profitable  alternatives  to  paddy.  The
vegetable area will increase by 65 and 150 percent in Nakhong and Chom Thong, respectively.
Paddy yields will increase from 2.0 to 3.0 t/ha in the wet season and from 3.0 to 5 t/ha in the dry
season. In Chom Thong, where the use of improved seed is relatively more common, wet season
crop yields will increase from 3.0 to 3.5 t/ha. The incremental production of paddy will be a result
of  improved  yields  and  a  small  increase,  around  10  percent,  in  the  irrigated  area.  But  it  will  be
partly offset by a small increases in area under vegetable and/or field crops.

25.
By applying these assumptions and parameters, representative farm models for both sites
were  generated.  Based  on  the  assumptions,  the  incremental  impact  on  farm  incomes  will  be
significant. In Nakhong and Chom Thong, the incremental income of the average household will
amount to about $300 and $160 per annum, respectively. The required levies, ISF and VDF, will
amount  to  about  18  percent  and  32  percent  of  the  corresponding  incremental  incomes.  After
project implementation, the cash flow of farming households will improve and the production base,
and hence capacity to manage risk, will be strengthened.

26.
Sensitivity  analysis  for  both  sites  shows  that  the  impact  of  all  measured  variables  at
household  level  is  insufficient  to  cause  a  negative  annual  cash  flow.  The  variables  having  an
impact  on  gross  margins  are  the  price  of  rice  and  dry  season  yields.  Although  a  20  percent
reduction  in  either  key  variable  will  significantly  reduce  net  profit,  it  does  not  result  in  either
negative cash flow or cash flows less than those attained  under  the without-project  scenario. In
summary, the analysis shows that after project implementation, farm cash flows will be sufficiently
robust to withstand fairly significant fluctuations without causing the farm household any financial
stress.

Project Benefits

Economic analysis for both sites is based on uniform assumptions, yields, and prices. The

difficult to quantify and were not included in the analysis.

Economic Life of the Project

28.
The overall economic life of the Project is 15 years. Field experience has shown that the
